user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_io_init:
```c
void metal_io_init(struct metal_io_region *io, void *virt,
	      const metal_phys_addr_t *physmap, size_t size,
	      unsigned int page_shift, unsigned int mem_flags,
	      const struct metal_io_ops *ops)
{
	const struct metal_io_ops nops = {
		NULL, NULL, NULL, NULL, NULL, NULL, NULL, NULL
	};

	io->virt = virt;
	io->physmap = physmap;
	io->size = size;
	io->page_shift = page_shift;
	if (page_shift >= sizeof(io->page_mask) * CHAR_BIT)
		/* avoid overflow */
		io->page_mask = -1UL;
	else
		io->page_mask = (1UL << page_shift) - 1UL;
	io->mem_flags = mem_flags;
	io->ops = ops ? *ops : nops;
	metal_sys_io_mem_map(io);
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_io_init:
struct metal_io_region {
	void			*virt;      /**< base virtual address */
	const metal_phys_addr_t	*physmap;   /**< table of base physical address
						 of each of the pages in the I/O
						 region */
	size_t			size;       /**< size of the I/O region */
	unsigned long		page_shift; /**< page shift of I/O region */
	metal_phys_addr_t	page_mask;  /**< page mask of I/O region */
	unsigned int		mem_flags;  /**< memory attribute of the
						 I/O region */
	struct metal_io_ops	ops;        /**< I/O region operations */
}
...
struct metal_io_ops {
	uint64_t	(*read)(struct metal_io_region *io,
				unsigned long offset,
				memory_order order,
				int width);
	void		(*write)(struct metal_io_region *io,
				 unsigned long offset,
				 uint64_t value,
				 memory_order order,
				 int width);
	int		(*block_read)(struct metal_io_region *io,
				      unsigned long offset,
				      void *restrict dst,
				      memory_order order,
				      int len);
	int		(*block_write)(struct metal_io_region *io,
				       unsigned long offset,
				       const void *restrict src,
				       memory_order order,
				       int len);
	void		(*block_set)(struct metal_io_region *io,
				     unsigned long offset,
				     unsigned char value,
				     memory_order order,
				     int len);
	void		(*close)(struct metal_io_region *io);
	metal_phys_addr_t (*offset_to_phys)(struct metal_io_region *io,
					    unsigned long offset);
	unsigned long	(*phys_to_offset)(struct metal_io_region *io,
					  metal_phys_addr_t phys);
}
...
typedef unsigned long metal_phys_addr_t
...
#define metal_sys_io_mem_map(__VA_ARGS__) 
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I found no uses of compiler-specific language extensions in the provided code. Items that might appear suspicious at first glance but are standard C features: 1) the restrict qualifier in the block_read/block_write prototypes is a standard C99 keyword, not a vendor extension; 2) the variadic macro form metal_sys_io_mem_map(__VA_ARGS__) is standard since C99; 3) fixed-width and standard integer types (uint64_t, size_t, unsigned long, CHAR_BIT) are from standard headers, not extensions; 4) aggregate initialization of the struct nops with NULL entries and the struct assignment io->ops = ops ? *ops : nops are standard C operations; 5) the use of -1UL, bit-shifts and sizeof are standard C expressions. No compiler-specific tokens (identifiers or keywords beginning with __ or containing compiler attributes such as __attribute__, __asm__, typeof (nonstandard in some compilers), or other known vendor extensions) or pragmas are present in the snippets. Therefore there are no code fragments that need investigation for Rule 1.2 based on the provided code.
